column1: The name Topeka is a Kansa-Osage sentence that means "place where we dug potatoes"
column2: or "a good place to dig potatoes". As a placename
column3: Topeka was first recorded in 1826 as the Kansa name for what is now called the Kansas River. Topeka's founders chose the name in 1855 because it "was novel
column4: of Indian origin and euphonious of sound."  The mixed-blood Kansa Native American
column5: Joseph James
column6: called Jojim
column7: is credited with suggesting Topeka's name. The city
column9: was one of the Free-State towns founded by Eastern antislavery men immediately after the passage of the Kansas–Nebraska Bill. In 1857
column10: Topeka was chartered as a city.

column1: The city is well known for the landmark U.S. Supreme Court case Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
column2: which overturned Plessy vs. Ferguson and declared racial segregation in public schools to be unconstitutional. The U.S. Navy has named three ships USS Topeka after the city.

column1: Topeka was a bastion for the free-state movement during the problems in Kansas Territory between abolitionist and pro-slavery settlers (the latter of whom controlled the legal government based out of Lecompton). After southern forces barricaded Topeka in 1856
column2: Topeka's leaders took actions to defend the free-state town from invasion. A militia was organized and stone fortifications were built on Quincy Street. The fortifications seemed to consist of low-lying earthwork levies strengthened by the presence of at least one cannon. The militia manned the fortifications until at least September 1856
column3: when the siege around the town was lifted.After a decade of abolitionist and pro-slavery conflict that gave the territory the nickname Bleeding Kansas
column4: Kansas was admitted to the Union in 1861 as the 34th state. Topeka was chosen as the capital
column5: with Dr. Charles Robinson as the first governor. In 1862
column6: Cyrus K. Holliday donated a tract of land to the state for the construction of a state capitol. Construction of the Kansas State Capitol began in 1866. It would take 37 years to build the capitol
column7: first the east wing
column10: using Kansas limestone. In fall 1864 a stockade fort
column12: was built in the intersection of 6th and Kansas Avenues to protect Topeka
column13: should Confederate forces then in Missouri decide to attack the city. It was abandoned by April 1865 and demolished in April 1867.

column6: the chief slave escape passage and free trade road.

column1: Topeka has struggled with the burden of racial discrimination even after Brown. New lawsuits attempted unsuccessfully to force suburban school districts that ring the city to participate in racial integration with the inner city district. In the late 1980s a group of citizens calling themselves the Task Force to Overcome Racism in Topeka formed to address the problem in a more organized way.

column3: Topeka was struck by a tornado rated F5 on the Fujita scale. It started on the southwest side of town
column4: moving northeast
column5: passing over a local landmark named Burnett's Mound. According to a local Indian legend
column6: this mound was thought to protect the city from tornadoes if left undisturbed. A few years prior to the tornado strike saw development near the mound including a water tank constructed near the top of the mound against the warnings of local Native Americans. The tornado went on to rip through the city
column7: hitting the downtown area and Washburn University. Total dollar cost was put at $100 million making it
column9: one of the most costly tornadoes in American history. Even to this day
column11: the Topeka tornado stands as one of the most costly on record. It also helped bring to prominence future CBS and A&E broadcaster Bill Kurtis
column12: who became well known for his televised admonition to "...take cover
column14: take cover!" on WIBW-TV during the tornado. (The city is home of a National Weather Service Forecast Office that serves 23 counties in north-central

column1: Topeka has a humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfa)
column2: with hot
column3: somewhat humid summers and cool to cold
column4: fairly dry winters
column5: and is in USDA Plant Hardiness Zone 6a. Over the course of a year
column6: the monthly daily average temperature ranges from 29.7 °F (−1.3 °C) in January to 79.0 °F (26.1 °C) in July. The maximum temperature reaches 90 °F (32 °C) an average of 41.5 afternoons per year and reaches 100 °F (38 °C) an average of 3.5 afternoons per year. The minimum temperature falls below 0 °F (−18 °C) an average of four mornings per year
column7: and there are 21 afternoons per year that stay below freezing. The average window for freezing temperatures is October 15 through April 17.The area receives nearly 36.5 inches (930 mm) of precipitation during an average year
column8: with the largest share being received in May and June—the April through June period averages 33 days of measurable precipitation. Generally
column9: the spring and summer months have the most rainfall
column10: with autumn and winter being fairly dry. During a typical year the total amount of precipitation may be anywhere from 25 to 47 inches (640 to 1
column11: 190 mm). Much of the rainfall is delivered by thunderstorms. These can be severe
column14: and sometimes tornadoes. There are an average of 100 days of measurable precipitation per year. Winter snowfall is light
column15: as is the case in most of the state
column16: as a result of the dry
column17: sunny weather patterns that dominate Kansas winters
column18: which do not allow for sufficient moisture for significant snowfall. Winter snowfall averages 17.8 in (45 cm). Measurable (≥0.1 in or 0.25 cm) snowfall occurs an average of 12.9 days per year
column19: with at least 1.0 in (2.5 cm) of snow being received on five of those days. Snow depth of at least an inch occurs an average of 20 days per year.

column1: The current mayor of Topeka is Michelle De La Isla.  The current Chief Executive Officer of the City of Topeka is City Manager Brent Trout. The City Manager is responsible to the Topeka's City Council
column2: which consists of the Mayor and nine members elected from separate districts within the city. The city council members select the Deputy Mayor from among themselves. The Deputy Mayor chairs the Committee of the Whole and represents the City of Topeka at official functions whenever the Mayor is unavailable. The City Manager also guides the council through the meetings but cannot vote.
